_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Policy:  Effingham Equity is committed to the prevention of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  Our prevention program includes the use of proper equipment, regular inspections and maintenance, and training for all employees that work with anhydrous ammonia.  Should an accidental release occur, the facility has oriented the local fire department and the county Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC).  These steps have been taken to ensure a quick response to any release and to minimize the impact of the release to the community and environment.



Facility Information:  The primary activity at the facility is the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia for sale to farmers.  Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient.



Worst Case/Alternative Case Scenario:  This facility has developed a worst case and alternative case scenario however it has been withheld from this executive summary as security sensitive information as requested by USEPA.



Accidental Release Program:  Effingham Equity complies with all rules and regulations relating to the storage and handling of anhydrous ammonia including the Illinois Department of Agriculture regulations as well as OSHA 29 CFR 1910.111.  Training is provided on safe anhydrous ammonia operations for all affected employees.



Five year Accident History:  There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia for the covered process in the past five years.  



Emergency Response Program:  Effingham Equity has a written emergency action plan in accordance with OSHA 29 CFR 1910.38.  Emergency Planning and Community Right to Know information is provided to thye Illinois Emergency Management Agency, LEPC, and the local fire department as required by SARA Title III of EPCRA.



Planned Changes to Improve Safety:  Improving safety at Effingham Equity is an on-going process.  Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe practic
es and operations.  There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
